dialogueHeader.title: TRIALL OF MR LOVE
dialogueHeader.author: unknown
dialogueHeader.contemporaneity: Source text dates from same year as the first printing / original speech event

textBibliography.frontMatter: THE WHOLE TRIALL OF M=R= LOVE, BEFORE THE HIGH COURT OF JUSTICE IN WESTMINSTER HALL. (...) PRINTED BY EXACT COPIES, OF THOSE WHO TOOK IT IN SHORT-HAND. ALL PUBLISHED FOR PUBLICK SATISFACTION. PRINTED IN THE YEAR, 1652. PP. 33.49 - 38.54 SAMPLE 1 PP. 40.23 - 44.54 SAMPLE 2 PP. 46.37 - 47.23 SAMPLE 3

nonSpeech.font: Major Adams is called into the Court, and sworn.

sample.dialogue: Declare your knowledge in this businesse?
Touching Alderman Bunce and Mason , I know something by relation touching the correspondency with them.
Tell the manner of it.
I conceive it was carried on by Mr. Drake , that is now absent; and in Scotland , by one Baily .
VVhat do you know of Mason , and of letters sent by him?
Mason I do know, and I do know he did receive letters.
From whom?
He said, from my Lord Piercy .
To whom were those letters communicated here?
They were communicated to M. Drake , and by M. Drake , to my selfe, and M. Alford , and C. Potter , and C. Far .
VVas M. Love privie to it?
I cannot say that, my Lord.
VVere there not letters sent to Scotland to them, and back again hither, about sending moderate propositions to the King?
There was such letters.
VVho writ them?
That I cannot tell.
Had Mr. Love a hand in them?
I cannot say he had. I cannot prove a negative, I cannot say he had not.
What know you of the petition sent to the King?
I know nothing of it, only I was told of it.
Who told you of it?
I cannot my Lord fix it upon any particular man, but I believe I was told of it by Alford , or Far , or Bains ; for I was not there at that time.
What do you know about the meeting at the Swan at Dowgate ?
My Lord I was not there.
Then my Lord, he may tell you what he doth know?

My Lord, upon our meeting in some place or other, I cannot tell where, I cannot tell the time, nor the place, but either at the Swan in Fish-street , or at the Swan at Dowgate , or in Cat-eaten street ; in one of these three places, I cannot punctually remember.
Who was at that meeting?
Mr. William Drake , Captain Titus , Major Alford , Captain Far , Captain Potter , and my selfe; and I do not know how many more, or whether any more, or no.
What past there?
It was there agreed, that Captain Titus should go over to Jersy .
What was he imployed about?

The end of his going, was to endeavour to work an agreement between the King and Scots , according to the Covenant. That was the end that was propounded. And in order to his going, wee did agree to furnish him with money for the present, and made some kind of promise to maintaine him while he was out.
What money was he furnished with?
I cannot be punctuall in that, but about a hundred pounds.
Who should pay it?
I paid twenty pounds of it, but I cannot tell who paid the rest.
To whom did you pay it?
To Mr. Drake .
My Lord, Ask him whether when this was sent to Jersy , was there not a return made?
Well, go on, There was your twenty pounds gone?
This is the substance of what I can say of his going.
Was this twenty pounds that you laid out of your owne, or did you collect it of some of the rest, or did you gather any of it again?
I cannot say that I did.
Did you not?
My Lord, I tell you the truth, I doe not know whether I did, or no: for I remember it was determined that we should gather it at that meeting?
Did not Mr. Love know of the collection?
I cannot say he did, it may be, he might, but I dare not say upon my oath, that he knew of it.
Ask him what return Titus made, what answer, and what account he gave?

M. Alford went to Calice to meet Titus , and Titus did send word that the Councell of State heard of his being there, and thereupon desired that some body might be sent over to him; for he had something to communicate which he could not well do by writing, and thereupon Mr. Alford was sent.
My Lord, Ask him where the letter was read?
The letter that Titus sent, was read by Mr. William Drake .
Where?
At his house, as I think, for I cannot certainly remember, I did not say, upon my Examination that it was read any where.
Whether were not you moved to go?
There was some motion to that end.
VVho moved it, and where?
VVho moved it, I cannot tell; it was moved, I think, in Mr. Loves Chamber.
Was Mr. Love there?
He was there.
Did Mr. Love move it?
I cannot say he did.
He will not say it?
I cannot say it upon my oath.
My Lord, so much he saith, that it was moved in Mr. Loves chamber, then he may give you an account of Mr. Alfords return, and where the account was given?
The returne of Mr. Alfords account was given at Mr. Loves house.
VVhat was it?
The return he made in generall was by a Narrative, and a copie of a letter from the King: there was with the Narrative that which was said to be the copie of a letter from the King.
What was the substance of that letter?

The
contents of the letter, as I remember, was first, he exprest a great deal of affection to the Ministry of England in generall, and promised great favour when he was in a condition to do it, and desired them to continue stedfast in the way they were in.
Was this letter published at Mr. Loves study?
It was read.
Was Mr. Love there?

Truly, to be positive, that Mr. Love was there, I dare not say; but Mr. Love was there at that meeting, either at the beginning or ending, but whether the letter was read at Mr. Loves house, I dare not swear; the Narrative from Titus , was a very long one, and very well drawn, I cannot give an account of it now: the whole of it was after this manner; To give an account to us of all the transactions that had happened since his going out of England , he did give an account of his usage by the Cavalier Party, that was against the Kings agreement with the Scots , because there was some did incline to his agreement with them, and there was another party was much against it, and he gave a very large account of that: after that he went on describing his disposition and condition.
This was the substance of the rest. Was there not some propositions for giving of thanks to Titus , for his so wel managing his affairs there?
There was a motion made by some body.
Who made the motion?
I cannot tell.
Was not an hundred pounds more to be sent agreed upon there?
I think so.
There was more money contributed; who agreed to lend any?
Sir, To that question, I cannot say, who propounded it; but that there was money sent.
Who contributed?
I did my share.
How much was that?
As I remember, ten pounds.
To whom did you pay it, and where did you pay it?

nonSpeech.font: Then they shewed him his Examination.

sample.dialogue: Come, look upon it, and be well advised.
I paid it to Mr. Drake at his fathers shop in Cheap-side.

Next about the Commission and instructions to be sent, what do you know of that? when this letter was read from the King, and published in Mr. Loves study, whether was there not a Commission agreed upon, to give instructions to treat with the King at Bredah ?
There was a motion made at Mr. Loves house, that there should be a commission and instructions drawn and sent; the motion was made at Mr. Loves house, they were there spoken of.
By whom, who did the Dialogue run between? Did Mr. Love do it?

Truely, for my part, I did not then take such speciall notice, that I dare at this time upon my oath, deliver any thing positively against any particular man, but generally all spake something, as I remember.
Was there any debate to mend the instructions?
Truly, Sir, not as I remember.
Did not Mr. Gibbons bring the rough draft of the Commission?

Truely, I think he did, as I remember he did, I have spoken of the Comission and instructions that were debated then and there, and that many of these persons here mentioned, were there; but that some of them mentioned, might not be there then, is very likely.
Was Mr. Love there?
That he was there some part of this time, I am very confident.
Was it in his study?
It was.
Was there a Commission agreed upon to be sent?
For the word agreed , I cannot tell what to say to it; Agreed, holds forth as if a vote passed.
Was there not a generall consent?
Being upon my oath, I desire to be cautious, for I must be tender in speaking the truth in this case, and I do not know what to make of the word agreed .
Was it approved of?

To my understanding the thing was thus, that at such meetings as these, we were not absolutely formall, as if we had been established by a Court of Justice, to act thus, and that there should be prefaces, and such things, or such methods observed, as that any man undertook to make a preface, either at the beginning, or conclusion, but it was spoken to by many persons, and by every person spoken to, and in this sense it was agreed.
Were there not instructions agreed upon, and all this in M. Loves study?
It was so.
Were they not read there?
I think they were.
Who read them?
I cannot tell who read them, but they were read, and I think Mr. Drake read them
What was the contents of the Commission?
The contents or the substance of the Commission was to this effect.

nonSpeech.font: This he reads out of his Examination.

sample.dialogue:
We the Presbyterians of England , do authorize you the Lord Willughby of Parham , Edward
Massey , Richard Graves , Cilas Titus , and James Bunce , to assist our Brethren, the Scotch Commissioners in their Treaty with the King, according to the instructions annexed; I dare not swear it in these words, but to this purpose it was; The substance of the instructions were to use all the arguments they could to move the King to give the Scotch satisfaction, and to take the Covenant; such arguments were mentioned, as the then condition of affaires best afforded, particularly how things stood in England at that time: which did all of them cry out for an agreement, and gave them full power as to all things, and what should be concluded by them, should be confirmed by these here; but I cannot say so, but what words were, were to this purpose, saving this conclusion, that what was concluded, should be confirmed here, I do not remember that.
Was there not some debate by what warrant they should act in this Commission and instructions?
There were some such words at the meeting.
What did Mr. Love say?

I cannot remember what Mr. Love did say, or whether he said any thing or nothing at that time, but that there were such words said, I have said it, but by whom, I cannot fix it upon any particular person.
Was it not debated by what warrant they should derive power to themselves to send this Commission?

There was such language, but by whom, I cannot say, I thinke by William Drake . It was because the King had writ this letter, wherein he desired there should be such instructions; there was something spoken of the secluded members, but by whom, I do not know; there was a Proposition whether the authority should be taken from the secluded Members, or from some other.
Did not Mr. Love then say, Come, let it go on.
I dare not say so.
Was it not propounded at the meeting to write to the Queen, and to Jermine , and Piercy , for them to mediate with the King to agree with the Scots .

nonSpeech.font: Adams's Examination was here againe read.

sample.dialogue: My Lord, So much of this, as I think to be true, I shall own.

Was there not a letter writ from Piercy , that a considerable summe of money was fit to be sent to the King, and what answer was given; was it not to be done till the King and Scots should agree, and then to raise the money?
That there was such a letter writ, I must needs acknowledge.
Where was it read? at Mr. Love's house?
No certainly, I onely saw it in Mason's own hands, and I remember he shewed it me.
Next ask him whether there was not a letter written about August last to some here, that Massey had back friends in Scotland , complaining he could not be promoted there?
I did understand there was such a letter, but by what way, I do not know.
Was not the letter communicated at M. Loves house, and were not you present when this letter was read at Mr. Loves house, wherein Massey complained he had back friends in Scotland ?
No certainly, that letter was not to my remembrance read there, I heard of such a letter, but saw it not.
My Lord, ask him whether he was not appointed to draw up some letters.
There were some I should have had a hand in drawing.
Who were appointed with you.
As I remember, Captain Potter , Captain Massey , and Mr. Gibbons .
But was there no meeting upon it, was M. Love named?
Mr. Love was not named.
Was there not one Sterks a Scotch Agent here, that kept intelligence from Scotland ?
I know, there was such a one, we took to be an Agent here.
Did he meet at your meetings?
Yes, he did meet sometimes.
Was he at Mr. Loves house at any time?
That he was.
When the Act came forth for banishing the Scots , was there not a collection for his charges, and were not you at M. Loves house when it was agreed to?
I was not.
Did you contribute money?
I did contribute 10 or 12s. I cannot tell which.
What discourse upon Dunbar fight was there from this person that is already spoken of?

This is the thing, if you please to help my memory; for there were so many particulars in this correspondency, that I cannot tell whereabouts it is I am to speak to, I am very uncertain where abouts it is I am SOURCE TEXT: a I m to speak to.
Speak the certainty as it was in your breast.
My Lord, if it be doubtfull to me, how can I be certaine, and charge it upon my memory?
Speak the truth?
I will speak the truth.
Do so then?

nonSpeech.font: Here again Adams looks upon his Examinations.

sample.dialogue: There is some of it I did set down, that I dare not own upon my oath, I then did deliver it so when I set it down.
Did Mr. Love know that this Scotch man was the Scotch Agent? did you not take notice that Mr. Love took notice of him?
I do think he did, as farre as I understand, he did.
Did not Mr. Love generally tell you the cause of the meetings?
No Sir.
Did you not hear Mr. Love say, that this Sterks was the Scotch Agent?
I never heard Mr. Love say so, but I knew this, that by our usuall meetings Mr. Love did understand him as I did, to be the Scotch Agent.
How often did you meet at Mr. Loves house?
I cannot tell, it may be seven, or eight, or ten times; an uncertain time.
He was at Mr. Loves study?
Whether so many times, I know not.
My Lord, ask him whether it was not at Mr. Loves study when mony was propounded to be raised for Massey , and Titus .
Was that in Mr. Loves study?
I cannot tell whether it was in his study, or in the lower room, I am apt to believe it was in the lower room.
Was Mr. Love there?
Certainly, he was there.
What was the contents of the letter?
The contents of the letter I cannot remember.
Whether did it not declare the poverty of his condition? And was it not after Dunbar fight?
Yes, it was.
Was this letter from Massey , read at Master Loves house, was this for money?
It was.
Was it agreed for money to bee raised?
If you take the word agreed , as I formerly propounded, it was so.
How was the money to be raised, and in what manner?
It was by those that were privy to the contribution.
Was not Mr. Love there, and did not he write down the sums that were to be contributed?
This I must needs say, that Master Love had papers in his hand, and hee did write something, but I did not see what he did write, and every man did write that was there.
Did not you conceive so, that Mr. Love summed up every mans sum? did he put the letter of their names before them, when he writ the sums?
I cannot say that.
Was not there a letter penn'd by Master Love , and Doctor Drake ?
To that question, I must say there was a letter, but I cannot deliver it upon my oath that it was penn'd by Master Love , or Doctor Drake , but it was taken to be so, and I thought it was so.
To whom was that letter directed?
I cannot tell to whom.
To whom was it declared to be directed? to whom was it declared to be written?
To the Generall Assembly and Kirk of Scotland .
Was this at Mr. Loves house too?
It was so.
Was Mr. Love present, and did approve of it?

Mr. Love was present at some time of this meeting: the reason why I thought it to be of Master Loves , or Doctor Drakes drawing, was nothing but meerly the language of it, it being in order to promote the ends of the Covenant, and all the whole language was couched to that purpose, and taking notice of the want of respect to Massey , and the English , and of their being beaten.
My Lord, This is very high; for he tels you this letter was approved of, and directed to be sent, and this was after Dunbar fight, after we were ingaged in bloud.
sample.nonSpeech: Here Adams read out of his Examination, as followeth :
sample.dialogue: There was also a large letter in the nature of a Declaration penn'd by Master Love , and Doctor Drake , and approved of by most of the Presbyterian party, Ministers, and other, and directed to the Generall Assembly, and Kirk of Scotland , subscribed by none, which contained the substance of what was declared by Titus , and Massey , but durst not promise any great sums of money till they appeared more considerable, and grew nearer action; the businesse required higher spirits then was for the present, and the businesse required a considerable summe: but to leave no means un-attempted when the businesse was feasable.
Major Adams is now upon his oath to tell you.
My Lord, As well as I remember, it did put forth much after this sort, but I cannot swear it in these words, but that is the substance of it.
Was not this agreed and declared at Mr. Loves house, that such a letter should be written to the Honourable Committee, and to the Kirk.
I answer, that after the same manner as all other things are agreed at such meetings as this is, but I have no ground, and do not know why I should say Master Love and Doctor Drake penn'd it.
Ask him for the substance of the letter, whether it were not as he hath told you, and whether he did not say, they could not promise a considerable sum of money.
Certainly, either in that letter, or some other, there was some such expressions.
VVell, it was about that time, and in that letter, or in some other letter, and at M. Loves house.

My Lord, Ask him if there was not an Agent come from Scotland , and a way laid at Kendall for a correspondency between these Gentlemen here, and some of Scotland , and whether one Groves was not sent thither?
That was something obscure; that there was such a thing, I do verily believe, because it went amongst us for a truth, but how to make it out for a truth upon my oath, I cannot tell.
Did Mr. Love know of it?
I do not know.
Ask him what he knows concerning Colonel Bamfield's man coming hither?
Concerning that I know nothing, but I confesse I had some Item , that at that time there was something found; and this is all I can say to that, I cannot guesse the time.
Was it after the fight at Dunbar ?
Yes, that it was.
Were the meetings at Mr. Loves house?
I cannot say all, but all that I know of, were.
Ask whether upon the large letter, Massey did not write that things were well setled in Scotland ?
Many of these things were understood so, and taken for granted amongst us, but I can say no otherwise, I thought it to be so; but I know not.
Were you not present, or at Mr. Loves house, when these letters were read, that they were in a hopefull condition?
I cannot say so.
What can you say?
As before, That it went for a truth amongst us, and that is as much as I can say to it.
Was there not a large letter inviting your friends to union?
I understand the other letter to be this you propound to me now.
Now we speak of a letter from Alderman Bunce , and others?
I cannot speak particularly to that; for I did not see them, but they were told me by one or other of those that were of the correspondency, and this is all I can say.
What is the truth? Doe you conceive it is so?
My Lord, we shall not trouble him with that, my Lord. Ask him one question more, What did Mr. Love tell you, that if the Presbyterians got the upper hand again?
Those words, I think, did but amount to this, that if the Presbyterians were in armes again, by the blessing of God, the Cavaliering party might be prevented from getting the day.
Who do you mean by the Correspondents?
By correspondents I mean Alford , Potter , Far , &c.
Was not Mr. Love one of them?
I took him to be so, my Lord.
My Lord, I pray ask him, whether any of these pretended or supposed letters, were ever received by me, any one of them, or that I writ one of them, or mended one of them.
I cannot say that ever I saw him do any such thing, nor did I ever see him write any.
But you saw the letters there?
That I have said.
Ask him whether I gave my consent to the sending away of this he calls a commission, and instructions, about the time of the Treaty at Bredah .
No, I will not swear that, and upon my oath I cannot.
Will you not, I will presse you to nothing, you said even now, you did not know he did send them away, but you did say, he was privy to them, and to the debates of them: did he declare any dissent?
I cannot say that.
Will you ask him this question? Whether he read the letters that he pretends were sent into England , or Scotland , or whether he heard them read?
That he swears?
I did not swear that these were the contents of them exactly. I was there when these letters were read.
He onely heard them read.

If there were halfe a score that had correspondency, and received letters, and come together, and one of the most confiding men read them, will any man say, that he will not believe these were right read, such a hear-say as this, is such a hear-say as you may take notice of.
But let him prove how it was a correspondency on my part.
I did not say that Mr. Love was one of the Correspondents, I deny that I said so, I said I conceived him to be so, but that is not, that he was so.
They did debate together, and met together, and received instructions, and therefore he may very aptly conceive he was a Correspondent?
Doth he swear that J assented?
J did not swear so?
He saith, money was sent to Titus , pray ask him whether by Agents J imployed?
Declare now what you know of this businesse.

My Lord, for the paper I was examined about, as for knowing Titus , I never saw him in my life but one quarter of an hour in a private house, and I knew nothing of his businesse any where. For the other, Alford coming over with letters, I was at Mr. Loves house, and when I was there, there was severall men there.
In what part of Mr. Loves house?

I conceive in his chamber, for I went up to severall that were there, whose names I can positively say, for two or three of them, though I cannot remember the other absolutely, though I conceive most I have named in my examination were there; C. Potter was there, and Doctor Drake , and M. Alford , and M. Love was there somtimes, though divers times he went out, some coming to speak with him.
Was there not a copy of a letter said to be sent from the King, read there?
I remember no such thing.
Was there not a narrative.
Yes, from Titus , wherein he declared the Kings inclinations to make peace with the Scots ; but that his wicked counsell about him did hinder it.
Was not this of what Titus had related from Jersey , the narrative of what had past between him and the King there?
I think it was.
Was not M. Alford sent to receive an account from him to Calice ?
William Drake did tell me so afterwards.
Did M. Alford deliver no account there?
I think it was M. Alford read the narrative.
Did he make no relation by word of mouth?
Truly, I cannot remember.
You cannot remember it was read?
Yes, I am sure it was read, and at Mr. Loves house.
And he was present sometimes?
Yes, sometimes.
What mony was there agreed upon to be provided for Titus ?
I know of none. It was moved by Captain Potter that there might be forty pounds, but I know of none, nor was it agreed by M. Love , M. Drake or my self, that we should lay down any at all.
Did you not meet with William Drake , and desire to go along with him to see Titus ?

I did so, but I think Drake desired it. I met him in Newgate market, and, saith he, I am going to see Titus , goe along with me; I said, I never saw him, nor did I know him: sayes he, You shall not stay at all: whereupon he went and found him in a Cheese-mongers house in New-gate market.
What discourse had you?

He said, he was newly come out of Holland , and he had been with the King, and he was a man of excellent parts for his years, and that he was inclinable to what was good, but that he had such desperate evill Counsell about him; and that hee did much pity him, and that his Clergie especially was wicked; and he propounded nothing to us, nor did I ever see his face afterwards, and this is about two years and a halfe ago; and for any other meetings at the Swan Taverne, or for any Agents, I never met him, or saw him.
Doe you not remember at any meeting, that there was money propounded for Captaine Titus , or for Alfords being sent over to Calice ? Speak what you know of that, and by whom it was told you?

Major Alford himselfe told me he was to meet his son, and he went over upon that score; but after he was gone, William Drake told me he was gone to see or meet Captaine Titus , I am not certaine of the words; and when he did come againe, which was the next time I heard of him, then William Drake comes to me, and desired mee to goe along with him, for I think he went up and down to every man.
You thinke then that William Drake was the prime man.
Yes, hee was the Actor and the Agent that moved all.
When Alford returned, he desired you to go with him.
To Mr. Loves house.
VVhat was done at Mr. Loves house ?

There were some papers read, which Alford , as I take it, read, or William Drake , I am not certaine which; but read it was, of a relation, that Titus came out of Iersy , and had seen the King there, and the Scots Commissioners, and that the King had a great inclination to agree with the Scots Commissioners, and that he was a man of excellent inclinations and parts, and had a great desire to agree, but his Counsell, and wicked crew about him would not let him; and he said, as I remember, that the King was a kind of a Prisoner with them there, and said, his Counsell did hinder him, or else, if he were from them, hee would agree with the Scots Commissioners.
You say, this paper was read; this Narrative was read, and in Mr. Loves house; was not Mr. Love present?
I am not able to say hee was, when I came in, I remember he was not in the roome, and he was there two or three times while I was there, but he was severall times called out.
Doe not you know there was an agreement of a letter written back to Titus ?
I can remember no such thing, but I think William Drake told me so, as I remember, but that was two years ago, I do verily believe by what I conceived, was of his writing.

I could wish that mens consciences could not bee scrupled to believe so much of a Minister, more then of a Magistrate; I hold it pernicious doctrine for any man to think he is bound more to obey the Minister, then the Magistrate: I ask you then before the Magistrate here, who was present at that meeting?
William Drake. I am sure, and Major Alford was there, and Captain Potter , and severall others, as I remember, Master Ienkyns .
This was in Mr. Loves house, was it not in his study?
I cannot tell that, I say, as I conceive, that Master Ienkyns , and Master Case were there, but positively I cannot say it, and Mr. Iackson , and Mr. Nalton , I think.
VVhat say you of Mr. Watson ?
I think he was there.
VVhat say you of Mr. Herring ?
I think he was.
VVhat say you of Mr. Cauton ?
In truth, I cannot tell.
VVhat say you of Mr. Robinson ?
I think he was.
What say you of Mr. Drake ?
Yes.
VVas Colonell Vaughan there?
Yes, I conceive he was there.
Was Master Iackson there?
Yes.
Was Capt. Far , and Capt. Potter there?
I believe so.
Was Mr. Gibbons there?
I cannot tell.
What say you of Mr. Sterks ?
No Sir, I do not know it.
Did you not know him to be the Scotch Agent? Was he not taken among you to be an Agent from Scotland ?
Yes, he was a Scotch man.
And for contribution of money, what money did you pay, and to whom?
Two five pounds to Mr. Drake .
For what use?
For charitable uses.
Then he asked it of you so, or for that purpose; but afterwards, What did you learn it was employed about?
Sir, he did not tell me how he did employ this money; but afterwards, I heard him say, that he had sent Titus money.
What did you contribute to Sterks his going into Scotland ?
Ten shillings.
And who else did contribute, that was there? and how much was the sum that was collected?
I cannot tell.
How much do you guess, or have heard?
Four or five pounds, I think.
Ask him who gave the Scotchmen money?

Truly, I did give several Scotchmen money, both to poor Ministers and others, that were banished by the Act, because I knew they were very poor, and knew not how to get away; and I did it out of charity towards them.
Because the State had an ill opinion of them, therefore you had a good opinion of them.
There was one Minister that had twelve children that was banished.
Were you at any meetings at Mr. Loves after Dunbar fight?
No not I.
At what Fast were you at, and who officiated at those Fasts?
I was at Major Adams , and Colonel Bartons .
Who did exercise at those Fasts? was Mr. Love , Mr. Jenkyns , Mr. Case , any of them?
I believe they were, I conceive so, I profess I cannot remember, I believe Mr. Jenkyns was there.
Was not Mr. Love one of them?
Yes, he was.
What was the occasion of those Fasts?
I know no particular occasion, but for the good of the two Nations.
How do you know they were for the good of the two Nations? was it not for an agreement between the King, and the Scots ?

I confess, it was for the Good of both Nations, as both Nations are the Church of God; and do both profess themselves Protestants, and of one Religion; and I conceived, it was my duty to pray for the good of them both.
But was there not some expressions for a blessing upon the Treaty at Breda ?
I cannot remember such expressions; for in such duties, I desire to have my heart lifted up unto God: And, my Lord, it is a great while ago.
Will you say your heart is lifted up unto God, when your understanding is in your heels?
My Lord, I do not remember one passage in prayer a week after.

That is in ordinary meetings, but this was for both Nations; but by what did you know, that this was for the good of both Nations, and why was it pretended to be for the good of both? and, my Lord, why they should not meet before, but just at that time, and at a private Fast?
I think that since the Nations of England and Scotland were at oddes, I have been at twenty Fasts.
My Lord, ask him, whether he were not late with Potter , and did not meet with him about Letters from Bamfield , and whither they went to read them?

This was about February or March last, he told me he received Letters, and desired me to go along with him to Mr. Loves , and after Dr. Drake came in, and then these Letters were read; and I profess, I know not from whence they came, nor the man; and so did Mr. Love declare, That he never saw, nor knew, nor heard of Bamfield before.
Did he not make mention of Parties in Scotland , that one party was for the King, another for the King and Kirk, a third neither for King, nor Kirk?
Yes.
But who were those he named, that were men for the King?
I think, Hamilton and his party.
And who for the King and Kirk?
Argile and Leshley .
And who neither for King nor Kirk?
Straughan and Car .
What, did he tell you of the young Kings escaping?
Something there was in that, but he was fetched back again.
What said he of Argile ?
Nothing at all, as I remember.
Was there not an expression, That they were now agreed to receive in the whole Nation, unless it were those that were notoriously scandalous and excommunicated?
I believe there was.
Did it not mention five thousand pounds for providing of shipping?
Yes; in the Narrative or Letter, whether there related at that time, I know not.
And what mention was there made, who were fit to command in England , if that party should come from thence into England ?
I conceive there was three Noblemen.
Name them.
My Lord of Suffolk , my Lord of Warwick , and my Lord of Manchester , or either of them.

That was propounded SOURCE TEXT: prepounded by Bamfield , but I hope those Lords were more noble, then to do any such thing: Was there not another Letter that came with that of Bamfields , sent by my Lord of Argile , and it was onely, That there should be an apbrobation of him: And was this Letter likewise read at the same time, and at the same place?
Yes, my Lord.
What was then propounded for money to be raised for Bamfield ?

Truly, Captain Potter did make mention for Forty pounds to be raised, Ten pounds for Colonel Bamfields man, and thirty pounds for Bamfield himself; but that business at the reading was wholly declined, and absolutely refused by all, to act any thing in that relation, in which it was sent over; whereupon, Captain Potter did move, that if nothing were done in that, whether it were not convenient to send the Messenger something to bear his charges; says he, If you will pay the messenger Ten pounds, and send Bamfield Thirty pounds, I will give the messenger the Ten pounds; but there was no Agreement, nor Conclusion, I know of, no Bill of Exchange that was sent, but Captain Potter said, he would lay down Ten pounds.
But no body spake against Captain Potters laying down of Ten pounds; and it was propounded to you to lend Ten pounds, and you said you would consider of it; but did Potter lend it?
I cannot tell that, my Lord, he said he would do it.

My Lord, let now Master Jaquel tell you what was the cause, why they did refuse to do any thing in the Letter about Five thousand pounds; what was the cause upon the debate between you at Mr. Loves house? why you did refuse to do any thing about the Five thousand pounds?
The debate was soon over; for we absolutely refused it, we would not meddle in it, not liking the business; it was a trouble, I am confident, to them that heard it read.
You do not remember that ever any body did acquaint the Magistrate with the design in working from Scotland ?
No, not I.
Did not some say, That Bamfield was a malignant?
I cannot tell, but I never heard of him before.
Were you not told he was a Cavalier, and of the Kings side, and that that was the true reason, why they would not trust him?
I do not remember any such thing.
Did Mr. Love agree for Ten pounds for Bamfields man, and Thirty pounds for Bamfield ?
No, I cannot say so.
Did not Major Alford tell you upon his return from Calice , that he was sent thither to take an account thence?
He did not, but William Drake did tell me, that he was gone to Calice to speak with Captain Titus .
And to take an account of the transaction at Jersey .
Truly Sir, I cannot say that, but William Drake told me, he was gone thither to speak with Titus ; and this is above two years ago, that William Drake told me so.
To what end?
To tell and hear news.
What did he do more?

I profess in the presence of God, I cannot tell Sir, I beseech you; for in the Paper I told you before, there were some circumstances, and something that I cannot say; but it was to this purpose, To speak with Titus , to hear the news from Jersey , but I cannot say certainly that word.

We do not press you to the word, but to the effect of it; my Lord, I think Mr. Jaquel hath given an account already, that this relation was at Mr. Loves house. Mr. Jaquel , let me bring one thing to your remembrance, if it be true, At your meeting at Mr. Loves house, upon this business of Bamfields Narrative, you say, Thirty pounds was moved to be sent to Bamfield , and Ten pounds to his man.
Yes, by Captain Potter .
And when it was then said, it was thought fit by Mr. Love , Mr. Drake , and Captain Potter , that it should be so done, whether did you not all agree it should be so done?
No, there was no agreement, but it was thought convenient, or to that purpose.
It was thought convenient by all the company present?
Truely Sir, there was not much regard taken in that businesse, nor was there much done; for we did not stay long, but there were such words.
But by all present?
Yes, there were such words.
Whether were not some friends at dinner at Dowgate , and was not Mason there?
My Lord, There was a Gentleman there, I cannot say, who he was, nor did I see him before or since.
Who did they tell you it was? did they not tell you, Mason ?
I professe, I cannot remember that, nor can I tell, but I conceive it was so.
In your Examination, you say it was Mason .
I said, I conceived so.
Why did you believe so?
I cannot tell, but as I remember, William Drake told me, It was so.
Whether when Bamfields letter came, and the letters from my Lord of Argile , Lowden , and others came, Was there not a letter from Baily ?
I do not remember, my Lord.
Nor from the Generall Assembly?
I do not remember any such thing.
Bethink your self, you are upon your oath, whether he that brought letters from Bamfield , did not bring letters from Baily , and from the Generall Assembly?
I cannot SOURCE TEXT: cannnot remember there was any such thing spoken of there.
Was there no expression of letters of thanks for the good affection of the Presbyterian party here, and encouragement to persevere?
I do not remember any such thing.
Was there no promises, that when they by their indeavours should get a free Parliament in England , that they would re-imburse all that was laid out
I do remember no such thing.
I would ask him some questions; and the first is, whether he hath spoken this as a meer relation, or whether he owns all this he hath spoken, as under an oath?
We are past that my Lord, he did say, he was under an oath.
If he say so, I am concluded.

nonSpeech.font: Mr. Jaquel made no answer to this.

sample.dialogue: You have asked two questions in a few words: for the first, whether he speak it under an oath; you know, that time was spent to declare it before he began: If you ask of his owne knowledge, you mistook it; for he saith something he hath by relation, and some that he knows: this hee hath taken notice of, what should wee further examine over the same thing; for he saith some of his own knowledge, some by relation from particular parties, and some from parties he cals not now to mind: and it was declared by the Court, that he was a witnesse, and the Court accepted him.

I desire your Lordship to ask him this question, whether the supposed Narrative that hee speaks of, that Alford said he brought over, and read at my house, was read at my house; or onely by Alford , and so brought over as news?
In truth, my Lord I cannot tell that.
He speaks of Sterks a Scotch man, I desire your Lordship to know wether hee knows, or can affirme by the oath you say he hath taken, that he was a Scotch Agent.

Sir, Ask him this question, he mentions a fast at Major Adams , or Col. Bartons , and that for the good of both nations; because he thought they were the Church of God; whether there was any intimation in that meeting, that it was under this notion, for the good of both Nations; whether that meeting was for the Scotch Nation to invade the English Nation.

nonSpeech.font: No answer to SOURCE TEXT: to to that question.

sample.dialogue: He said, (if I have taken him rightly, and if not, I desire your Notaries to inform me better) that Mr. Love did not agree to such a summe as forty pounds, and afterwards hee said, that all there said, it was convenient. Now I would ask how these two can agree together?
You are right; for the thing of agreement he disclaimed totally.
Then I did not agree to it.
No, nor any else.
But afterwards he sayes, that they did conceive it was convenient; Now, I pray ask him, how he knew that I thought it was convenient?
I cannot say any thing that Mr. Love did say it was convenient; but it was not dissented from, nor spoken against by any, as I remember.

sample.nonSpeech: Captain Far is called into the Court, and is sworn .
sample.dialogue: My Lord, let him acquaint you with what passed at the White Hart in Breadstreet .
I desire the benefit of my Papers.
At whose request did you come to the white Hart in Breadstreet , and when was it?
By William Drake .

Was that the first time you were acquainted with any thing of this nature, for carrying on and prosecuting of an order, to the furtherance of an Agreement between the Scots , and the King? VVhat do you know of that, at what time was the meeting?
It was about two years since.
VVhat was the discourse at that meeting?
It was the drawing up of some heads of a Letter, which might be sent to Scotland .
What was the effect of it?
It was to this effect, to the best of my memory; for it is so long since.
sample.nonSpeech: Here Captain Far was at a stand, whether through infirmity of speech (for he seemed to be slow of speech) or otherwise, I cannot say; and he or the Attorney General for him, made great use of the Papers of his Examination .
sample.dialogue: To desire them, the better to bring them to an agreement, that there might be moderate Propositions.
It was to moderate their desires in the agreement, between the King and the Scots .
What to do?
That they might abate of their demands.
Of their former demands, that they might be the more like to agree; was it not so?
Yes, my Lord.
Was it not propounded likewise, that some should be sent to the King, to perswade him to give satisfaction to the Scots ?
It was propounded by Titus , but not approved of.
But did you not agree to send to the Scots that you did agree to, and were there not heads which Titus , or Drake , did undertake to write, and afterwards were drawn up?
I saw no letters.
But did not Drake tell you he had sent them to Master Baily in Scotland ?

nonSpeech.font: Captain Far being at a stand, the Atturny Generall asketh him again.

sample.dialogue: Did not William Drake tell you, a letter was sent accordingly into Scotland ?
Yes he did tell me, he had sent letters.

My Lord, let him give you Lordship an account before the Treaty at Jersey , where Drake met with him, and what he propounded to him, whether to send to Jersey , and what persons, and upon what message?
Mr. Drake did say, that Captain Titus did say, It was requisite for one to be at the Treaty at Jersey , and I had it from Drake , that Titus did undertake to go himselfe thither.
What was his imployment to be there, and what money was to be raised for him? -- Did he tell you he wanted money?

After Mr. Drake desired, I would help him to ten pounds, and Titus was in want of money to relieve his necessities; and upon this request I did leave ten pounds in Mr. Drakes Ware-house. ATTORNEY-GENERAL SPEAKS: VVas Drake present?
I think he was, I was promised it again, but never received it.

My Lord, Let him inform after this negotiation of Titus was ended at Iersy , whether there was not a letter written by Titus , and whether this was not read in the presence of Mr. Love , and some others, and whether at Mr. Loves or no?

Upon the ending of the Treaty at Iersey , and Bredah , were you not present at Mr. Loves house, when it was signified from Titus , that it was not convenient for him to come into England , because he thought he was discovered to the Councell of State, and desired some body to be sent to Calice to take an account there of his negotiation?
Yes, my Lord, I was there.
